thread.title_full: Florida teen creates company to give teddy bears to fallen officers' families - Orlando Sentinel

author: orlandosentinel.com
title: Florida teen creates company to give teddy bears to fallen officers' families
text:
Megan O’Grady is helping grieving families of fallen police officers one teddy bear at a time.
The 14-year-old student from Cape Coral founded Blue Line Bears, a nonprofit organization that provides the children of slain officers with a stuffed bear made from their parent’s uniform.
Megan’s inspiration to spearhead the project began with a required essay for school, in which she had to write about “something she believed in.” As the daughter of a Southwest Florida police officer, she was motivated to write about her father’s work.
“Police officers aren’t treated as respectfully as they should be treated,” Megan said.
Once the fallen officer’s uniform shirt is delivered to her father’s police department, Megan gets to work.
Since January, Megan, with help from her grandmother, has stitched seven keepsake bears, complete with the officer’s department patch, a personalized badge and stripes indicating the officer’s rank or service. Donations to the organization cover the cost of materials as well as shipping. She delivered them this week.
Each bear is given a St. Michael medal, which is often worn by officers as a prayer for protection and blessed by a priest before the family receives it free of charge.
Her mother, Suzie O’Grady, said that her daughter has received at least 20 more bear requests via Facebook, including one from a woman whose brother was killed in the line of duty during the 1980s. It takes her five to six hours to create each bear.
“It’s remarkable to see her have such purpose,” Suzie O’Grady said. “To see that she can make a difference in the world at her age is inspiring to us as parents.”
Megan presented her first handmade bear Monday to Johnny Brinson, the son of fallen Orlando police Lt. Debra Clayton .
Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the force, was fatally shot in January while confronting murder suspect Markeith Loyd , who was wanted in the December death of his pregnant ex-girlfriend.
The bear was created from different parts of Clayton’s uniform shirt, Megan said. The black buttons adorning her uniform were used for the stuffed animal’s nose and eyes. Extra fabric from Clayton’s shirt was used to sew a personalized badge with her last name and badge number on the bear’s stomach.
Brinson ran his fingers along the three-striped insignia on the bear’s left arm, directly below the embroidered uniform patch bearing “Orlando Police.”
He thought he would never see or feel the patch again, Brinson said after he was presented with the bear Monday. The stuffed bear is “one of the best” gifts he has received, he added.
“I always hugged her in her uniform, even before she went to work,” Brinson said. “We were that close. We talked every day, every hour.”
Orlando Police Chief John Mina said he was overcome with joy when he heard how Megan was helping families cope with the loss of a loved one.
“When I found out [the bears] were actually going to be made out of Debra’s uniform, it was hard not to get emotional,” Mina said. “It just means the world to us.”
A few hours after the presentation, Megan delivered three teddy bears to the family of Orange County Deputy 1st Class Norman Lewis, 35, who was killed in a traffic crash while helping search for Loyd on Jan. 9.
Megan is not limiting herself just to Florida. She is already creating teddy bears for grieving families living in New York, Illinois, Nevada and other states.
“We want to make it nationwide so that everyone can feel the same love as the people we’ve visited so far,” Megan said. “We want to reach out and impact people’s lives.”
